There is no definitive answer to which language - Russian or Spanish - is harder to learn, as it depends on various factors such as individual linguistic background, natural aptitude for languages, and the resources available for learning the language. However, considering some aspects of both languages might help you decide which one could be more challenging for you.

1. Alphabet: Russian uses the Cyrillic alphabet, while Spanish uses the Latin alphabet (the same one used in English). If you are not familiar with the Cyrillic alphabet, it may take some time to learn and become comfortable with reading and writing in Russian.

2. Pronunciation: Both languages have their own unique phonetic systems that differ from English but generally speaking; Spanish pronunciation can be considered easier compared to Russian due its smaller number of vowel sounds and clear phoneme-grapheme correspondence.

3. Vocabulary: While both languages have many loanwords from other languages like English or French especially in scientific context making vocabulary somewhat less challenging at times ,they both also require memorizing a considerable amount of new words. In general terms though if one had previously experience with another Romance Language  they would find spanish considerably easy since these share common lexical roots versus Russian lacking this characteristic although being an Indo-European Language

4.Grammar:
While grammar itself usually poses challenges always when learning anew language some particularities ought stand out.Spanish has verb conjugations based upon tense,mood,personal subject pronouns meaning they effectively present different morphological markers indicating assorted relationship within sentences
Russian on its part posseses a complex case system where noun endings change according what role phrase takes thus more features make up russian declension processes(6 cases) than those taken into account by spanish esentially changing articles.Similarly verbs undergo numerous changes mainly
